newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden paves way for SAS stake reduction.
newsitem.headline: Sweden paves way for SAS stake reduction.

text.p: The Swedish government will on Friday pave the way for a cut in its stake in Scandinavian Airlines System (SAS) to a possible 35 percent from its present 50 percent, a government offical said on Monday.

A selloff could help pay estimated SAS bills of $5.5 billion over the next 10 years for new aircraft and other expenses, although the government says that its request to parliament for enabling legislation does not mean that a sale is imminent.
"To reduce the state's stake is not on the agenda right now," Stefan Back, deputy assistant undersecretary at the Communications Ministry, told Reuters.
The proposal would also extend Sweden's SAS alliance with Norway and Denmark to the year 2020.
The partners have for years discussed changes which would make it easier to attract new capital to SAS.
"The three companies holding SAS have recently been streamlined to become easier to invest in," Back said.
Back said it was still unclear to what level state ownership could be reduced, but a figure of 35 percent had been mentioned.
Main private owners of SAS Sweden are the Wallenberg family's key holding company Investor, with 18.5 percent and Swedbank funds with 10.9 percent.
